awd_titl_txt: A Targeted Approach to Delineating the Source(s) and Optical Properties of CDOM
awd_abstract_narration:
A Targeted Approach to Delineating the Source(s) and Optical Properties of Chromophoric Dissolved Organic Matter

The colored components of dissolved organic matter (DOM) absorb light to varying degrees in all natural waters. This material, known as colored or chromophoric dissolved organic matter (CDOM), plays an essential role in determining the color of natural waters and influences the amount of ultraviolet and visible light that penetrates into water bodies. Because CDOM absorbs strongly in the ultraviolet, it can protect aquatic organisms from damaging radiation, whereas its absorption in the visible can reduce the amount of light available for photosynthesis, thus potentially affecting aquatic ecosystems. The absorption of light by CDOM also initiates a series of photochemical reactions, which produce reactive oxygen species that can transform CDOM and other compounds, and affect the availability of essential trace metals to aquatic organisms. Despite its established importance in aquatic chemistry, the compounds and structures that give rise to light absorption and emission and produce the photochemical reactions are still poorly understood. This work will use a series of laboratory tests to identify chemical groups within the CDOM that influence its optical and photochemical properties and how these vary with source.

These tests (and the information they can provide) include: 1) the effect of sodium borohydride reduction on the optical absorption and emission properties (contribution of ketones/aldehydes to optical properties); 2) pH dependence of the spectral absorption and emission before and after borohydride reduction (identify contributions of carboxylic acids and phenols and possible electronic interactions between these groups and ketones/aldehydes); 3) the effect of anoxic dithionite reduction on the optical properties (content and impact of quinones to optical properties); 4) molecular size dependence of the optical properties of CDOM from differing sources/locales and how this may be affected by borohydride reduction and pH. This work will focus on laboratory studies of humic substances and of archived samples of CDOM acquired in past field work from diverse oceanic and freshwaters sites, but will be augmented by samples collected from the Chesapeake Bay through a complementary collaboration with a NASA project that aims to examine water quality in shellfish beds through direct sampling and optical remote sensing.

This proposal will further support plans to initiate a program for talented and gifted students at Kenmoor Middle School in the Prince George’s County Public Schools in Maryland. Plans for this program include presentations/demonstrations to the students and faculty at the middle school that are related to the goals of this project, followed by a visit of an interested, select group of students to the PI’s laboratory where they will be allowed to see and operate some of the scientific instruments employed in this project and be involved in additional hands-on demonstrations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

PROJECT OUTCOME REPORT

The absorption of light by the colored components of dissolved organic matter (DOM) occurs to varying degrees in all natural waters. This material, known as colored or chromophoric dissolved organic matter (CDOM), plays an essential role in determining the color of natural waters and the penetration of ultraviolet and visible light into water bodies. Because CDOM absorbs strongly in the ultraviolet, it can act to protect aquatic organisms from damaging radiation, while its absorption in the visible can act to reduce the amount of light available for photosynthesis, thus potentially affecting ecosystem structure. The absorption of light by CDOM also initiates a series of photochemical reactions, which produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) that can in turn lead to the photooxidation of the CDOM and other compounds, as well as affect the availability of essential trace metals to aquatic organisms. Despite its established importance in aquatic chemistry, the compounds/structures that give rise to light absorption and emission and produce the photochemical reactions are still poorly understood.  This work employed a series of chemical procedures to test for the presence of distinct molecular groups or moieties within the CDOM that contribute to the optical and photochemical properties and how these might vary with source.

These tests included: 1) the effect of sodium borohydride reduction on the optical absorption and emission properties to assess the contribution of ketones/aldehydes to optical properties; 2) pH dependence of the spectral absorption and emission before and after borohydride reduction to test for the contributions of carboxylic acids and phenols, as well as possible electronic interactions between these groups and the ketones/aldehydes; 3) the effect of anoxic dithionite reduction on the optical properties to examine the content and impact of quinones to optical properties. This work focused not only on laboratory studies of model compounds, CDOM standards (humic substances) and archived samples of CDOM extracts acquired in past field work from diverse oceanic and freshwaters sites, but also on samples collected from the Chesapeake Bay in a complementary collaboration with a NASA project that aimed to detect poor water quality in shellfish beds through direct sampling and optical remote sensing.

Based on studies of model quinones (p-benzoquinones, napthoquinones, anthroquinones) and ketones/aldehydes, we found that dithionite selectively reduces quinones, while borohydride reduces ketones/aldehydes, and quinones, and thus that dithionite can be used to isolate the effects of quinone moieties on the optical properties. Dithionite reduction of CDOM standards and natural water extracts from the North Pacific Ocean, the Equatorial Atlantic Ocean and the Chesapeake Bay exhibited only minor changes in absorption and fluorescence, whereas significant changes were observed for borohydride reduction, indicating that the changes in optical properties under borohydride reduction can be attributed primarily to ketones/aldehydes rather than quinones. Model quinones further showed significant changes in fluorescence intensity and maximum emission wavelength under dithionite reduction; these changes were not observed for CDOM standards and the natural water extracts, further supporting the conclusion that the contribution of quinones to CDOM optical properties is generally small or negligible.

Optical responses to pH and borohydride reduction were nearly identical for extracts from differing regions within the Chesapeake and Delaware Bays and a CDOM standard (Suwannee River Fulvic Acid, SRFA), suggesting a similar chromophore content throughout both Bays and that CDOM within the Bays was dominated by a terrestrial source. In contrast, coastal and offshore surface waters differed significantly, suggesting either 1) biological or photochemical modification of a terrestrial source, 2) the in situ formation of CDOM from a biological source, or 3) some combination of both processes. Surprisingly, optical responses to pH and borohydride reduction for deep ocean extracts from the Atlantic and Pacific were highly similar, suggesting a commonality in chromophore content in the deep waters of both ocean basins.

In related photochemical work, direct evidence of a light-dependent reaction of superoxide, a ROS, with light-generated species within CDOM was acquired. This finding has implications for a possible superoxide-driven pathway of CDOM degradation that had not been previously identified.
